text: But the king shall rejoice in God; every one that sweareth by him shall glory: but the mouth of them that speak lies shall be stopped.
text_kjv: But the king shall rejoice in God; every one that sweareth by him shall glory: but the mouth of them that speak lies shall be stopped.
text_niv: But the king will rejoice in God;all who swear by God’s name will praise him,while the mouths of liars will be silenced.
text_esv: But the king shall rejoice in God; all who swear by him shall exult, for the mouths of liars will be stopped.
text_nlt: But the king will rejoice in God.All who swear to tell the truth will praise him,while liars will be silenced.
text_msg: But the king is glad in God;his true friends spread the joy,While small-minded gossipsare gagged for good.
text_nasb: But the king will rejoice in God; Everyone who swears by Him will glory, For the mouths of those who speak lies will be stopped.
context: Psalm 63 is attributed to David, written when he was in the wilderness of Judah, likely during his flight from his son Absalom (2 Samuel 15-18). This was a period of intense personal turmoil, betrayal, and physical hardship for David. The wilderness was a desolate, dry, and dangerous place, devoid of the comforts and security he was accustomed to as king. Water was scarce, and the constant threat of enemies and wild animals loomed. The Psalm reflects David's deep longing for God's presence and power amidst these desperate circumstances. 'Swearing by' God was a common practice indicating allegiance, covenant commitment, and truthfulness. It meant invoking God as a witness to the oath, acknowledging His authority and expecting His judgment should the oath be broken. In ancient Near Eastern cultures, oaths were taken very seriously, and calling upon a deity to witness an oath carried significant weight. Lying and deception were considered grave offenses, especially against the king or established authority. The 'stopping of the mouth' implies silencing those who speak falsehood, either through divine judgment or the exposure of their deceit, bringing them to shame and rendering their words ineffective. This verse encapsulates the justice system and the societal values of the time, where truth and loyalty were prized, and falsehood was punished.
meaning: Psalm 63:11 presents a stark contrast between those who are loyal to God and those who are deceitful. 'The king shall rejoice in God' speaks of the righteous ruler who finds his strength, joy, and confidence in his relationship with God. This rejoicing isn't merely happiness, but a deep-seated, unwavering trust and satisfaction rooted in God's faithfulness. 'Every one that sweareth by him shall glory' refers to those who are loyal to God and the king (representing divinely appointed authority). By swearing by God, they acknowledge His sovereignty and commit to truth and obedience. Their glory is not in themselves but in their faithfulness to God. It signifies honor, vindication, and a blessed life as a result of their allegiance. This part reinforces the importance of covenant fidelity and the blessings that follow. Conversely, 'the mouth of them that speak lies shall be stopped' highlights the inevitable consequences of deceit and rebellion against God. 'Stopped' signifies the judgment that awaits those who spread falsehoods. Their lies will be exposed, their influence will be silenced, and their plans will be thwarted. This isn't just a physical silencing, but also a metaphorical one - their words will lose their power, and their credibility will be destroyed. The verse affirms God's commitment to justice and the eventual triumph of truth over falsehood. It underscores the moral order of the universe, where integrity and loyalty are rewarded, and deceit is punished. The verse presents a theological framework where God actively intervenes in human affairs to uphold righteousness and protect those who trust in Him.
application: Psalm 63:11 provides profound guidance for modern living. As believers, we are called to 'rejoice in God' – not just when life is easy, but even in the wilderness experiences of life. This means cultivating a deep, abiding relationship with God, finding our joy and strength in His presence through prayer, scripture, and fellowship. In a world saturated with misinformation and deception, we are called to be people of truth, those who 'swear by him' in our words and actions. This isn't about taking literal oaths, but about living with integrity, honesty, and faithfulness in all our dealings. It means aligning our lives with God's principles and being a beacon of truth in a world that often embraces falsehood. We must be discerning in the information we consume and share, guarding against the spread of lies and misinformation. The verse challenges us to actively stand against injustice and speak up for truth, even when it's difficult or unpopular. We should support and encourage those who live with integrity, and gently correct those who are engaging in deception. Furthermore, the promise that 'the mouth of them that speak lies shall be stopped' offers hope and reassurance that ultimately, truth will prevail. We can trust that God is working behind the scenes to expose deception and bring justice. This doesn't mean we should passively wait for God to act, but rather actively participate in promoting truth and righteousness while trusting in His sovereignty. Living out this verse requires a commitment to personal integrity, a dedication to truth, and a unwavering faith in God's justice. It calls us to be agents of change, transforming our world one act of truth and righteousness at a time.
prayer: Heavenly Father, in the midst of the wilderness experiences of my life, I long for your presence and your peace. Help me to rejoice in you, even when circumstances are difficult and discouraging. Grant me the strength to be a person of truth, to 'swear by you' in my words and actions. Give me discernment to recognize and reject falsehood, and courage to speak up for what is right. Lord, I trust in your promise that the mouth of those who speak lies shall be stopped. Strengthen my faith in your justice, and empower me to be an agent of truth and righteousness in the world. Help me to live a life that honors you, and to find my joy and satisfaction in your unwavering love. In Jesus' name, Amen.

faqs.answer: To 'rejoice in God' means to find deep, unwavering joy, peace, and satisfaction in our relationship with Him, regardless of external circumstances. It's a confident trust in His faithfulness and provision, even in hardship.
